The announcement must be confirmed by official Bank of England communications, such as press releases, Monetary Policy Committee statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, the condition is not met.

Given this condition, will India not eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 31, 2024? This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Indian government does not officially announce or implement a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products. The policy must not be confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Any reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will not be sufficient for a NO resolution. If such a policy is introduced or implemented by the resolution date, or if only partial measures are taken, the question resolves as YES.

para_P.title: If the Bank of England declares an interest rate reduction by August 2024, will India remove export duties on agricultural goods by July 2024?
para_P.body:
Assume the following holds true: The Bank of England makes an official statement regarding an interest rate reduction to take effect by August 31, 2024. This announcement must be validated through official communications from the Bank of England, such as press releases, statements from the Monetary Policy Committee, or public addresses by Bank representatives. If no such declaration occurs by the resolution date, the condition is not satisfied.

Under this premise, will India abolish export duties on agricultural goods by July 31, 2024? This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Indian government makes an official declaration or enacts a policy to fully abolish export duties on agricultural goods. The policy must be corroborated by official government announcements or reported by at least two credible international news organizations (like Reuters, Bloomberg, or the Associated Press). Merely reducing export duties partially or eliminating them only for certain agricultural products will not suffice for a YES answer. If no such policy is enacted or introduced by the resolution date, or if only partial actions are taken, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) The Bank of England announces an interest rate cut by August 2024 (b) India eliminates export taxes on agricultural products by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES only if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The Bank of England officially announces an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed by official Bank of England communications, such as press releases, Monetary Policy Committee statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. The actual implementation date of the rate cut can be after August 31, 2024, as long as the announcement itself occurs by that date. The interest rate in question refers to the Bank Rate, which is the Bank of England's primary tool for monetary policy. (b) The Indian government officially announces or implements a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 31, 2024. The policy must be confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Partial reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will not be sufficient for a YES resolution. If either of these conditions is not met by their respective resolution dates, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will at least one of the following not occur: (a) The Bank of England announces an interest rate cut by August 2024 (b) India does not eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if at least one of the following conditions is met: (a) The Bank of England does not officially announce an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024, or the announcement is not confirmed by official Bank of England communications, such as press releases, Monetary Policy Committee statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. The actual implementation date of the rate cut can be after August 31, 2024, as long as the announcement itself does not occur by that date. The interest rate in question refers to the Bank Rate, which is the Bank of England's primary tool for monetary policy. (b) The Indian government does not officially announce or implement a policy to completely eliminate export taxes on agricultural products by July 31, 2024, or the policy is not confirmed by official government communications or reported by at least two reputable international news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). Partial reductions in export taxes or the elimination of taxes on only some agricultural products will be sufficient for a NO resolution. If both of these conditions are met by their respective resolution dates, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Are both of the following events going to take place: (a) The Bank of England will declare a reduction in interest rates by August 2024 (b) India will abolish export duties on agricultural goods by July 2024?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as YES only if both of the following criteria are satisfied: (a) The Bank of England formally announces a reduction in interest rates to take effect by August 31, 2024. This announcement must be verified by official communications from the Bank of England, such as press releases, statements from the Monetary Policy Committee, or public addresses by Bank officials. The actual date when the rate reduction takes effect may be after August 31, 2024, provided the announcement occurs by that date. The interest rate in question pertains to the Bank Rate, which is the primary instrument for monetary policy used by the Bank of England. (b) The Indian government officially declares or enacts a policy to entirely remove export duties on agricultural goods by July 31, 2024. This policy must be corroborated by official government communications or reported by at least two credible international news organizations (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, or Associated Press). A partial reduction in export duties or the removal of duties on only certain agricultural products will not suffice for a YES resolution. If either of these criteria is not fulfilled by their respective resolution dates, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Mexican economy avoid a recession by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Mexican economy does not enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

not_P.title: Will the Mexican economy enter a recession by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Mexican economy does enter a recession. For the purpose of this question, a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

para_P.title: Will Mexico's economy steer clear of a recession by the end of July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, by July 31, 2024, the economy of Mexico does not fall into a recession. For the purposes of this question, a recession is characterized as two successive quarters of declining GDP growth as indicated by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The inquiry will be deemed negative if Mexico's economy undergoes two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time from October 1, 2023, through July 31, 2024.

question.title: Conditional on the Mexican economy avoiding a recession, will Sony Corporation resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: The Mexican economy avoids a recession by July 31, 2024, meaning it does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024, as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico.

Then, will Sony Corporation reach an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by July 31, 2024? For this to resolve as YES:

1. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Sony Corporation workers.
2. The strike must last at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO. If the condition about the Mexican economy is not met, this question resolves as N/A.

not_P.title: Conditional on the Mexican economy experiencing a recession, will Sony Corporation not resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: The Mexican economy experiences a recession by July 31, 2024, meaning it does experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024, as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico.

Then, will Sony Corporation not reach an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by July 31, 2024? For this to resolve as YES:

1. The strike must involve at least 1,000 Sony Corporation workers.
2. The strike must last at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If such a resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if a significant strike does occur, the question resolves as NO. If the condition about the Mexican economy is met, this question resolves as N/A.

para_P.title: Assuming the Mexican economy remains stable without entering a recession, will Sony Corporation successfully conclude a significant workers' strike by July 2024?
para_P.body:
Let's consider the following scenario: The Mexican economy maintains its stability and avoids a recession by July 31, 2024, which means it does not undergo two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth from October 1, 2023, to July 31, 2024, according to the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico.

Under these circumstances, will Sony Corporation come to a resolution with its unionized workforce, thereby ending a major strike by July 31, 2024? For this to be confirmed as YES:

1. The strike must involve a minimum of 1,000 workers from Sony Corporation.
2. The strike must persist for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be validated by official announcements from both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
4. The resolution must be covered by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no resolution meeting all these conditions is reached by the specified date, or if there is no significant strike, the question will conclude as NO. If the condition regarding the Mexican economy is not fulfilled, this question will conclude as N/A.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Mexican economy avoids a recession and (b) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Mexican economy does not enter a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy experiences two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If both conditions are not met by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Mexican economy avoids a recession nor (b) Sony Corporation resolves a major workers' strike?
not_P.body:
This question resolves as YES if neither of the following conditions are met by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Mexican economy does enter a recession. A recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth as reported by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The question resolves as NO if the Mexican economy does not experience two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any point between October 1, 2023, and July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the continuation of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must not involve a substantial number of Sony Corporation workers (fewer than 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must not last for at least one week.
   3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Sony Corporation and the involved union.
   4. The resolution must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If either condition is met by the specified date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that by July 2024, both of the following will take place: (a) the Mexican economy remains out of recession and (b) Sony Corporation successfully ends a significant workers' strike?
para_P.body:
This inquiry is answered with YES if the following two criteria are fulfilled by July 31, 2024:

(a) The Mexican economy does not fall into a recession, which is characterized by two successive quarters of negative GDP growth as indicated by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography of Mexico. The answer will be NO if the Mexican economy suffers two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth at any time from October 1, 2023, to July 31, 2024.

(b) Sony Corporation must come to a consensus with its unionized workforce, bringing an end to a major strike by July 31, 2024. For this resolution to be considered valid:
   1. The strike must engage a significant number of Sony Corporation employees (at least 1,000 participants).
   2. The strike must continue for a minimum of one week.
   3. Confirmation of the resolution must come from official announcements by both Sony Corporation and the relevant union.
   4. The resolution must be covered by at least two credible international news outlets (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If either of these conditions is not satisfied by the given date, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Will California conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, California conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If no such referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

not_P.title: Will California not conduct a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, California does not conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. For a YES resolution, the following criteria must be met:

1. The referendum must not be officially announced and conducted by the state of California.
2. The primary focus of the referendum must not be on abortion rights protection.
3. The referendum results must not be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

If such a referendum meeting these criteria occurs by August 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

para_P.title: Is there a plan for California to hold a vote on abortion rights before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, California holds a public vote specifically aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within the state. For an affirmative outcome, the following conditions must be satisfied:

1. The vote must be officially declared and carried out by the state of California.
2. The main emphasis of the vote must be on safeguarding abortion rights.
3. The results of the vote must be disclosed by official state sources or widely acknowledged news outlets.

If no such vote that fulfills these conditions takes place by August 31, 2024, the inquiry will be deemed negative. It is important to note that simply suggesting or planning a vote without actually executing it by the specified deadline does not meet the criteria for an affirmative outcome.

question.title: Given California conducts a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024, will Oregon also hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, California conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California, with the primary focus on abortion rights protection, and the results publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

Then, is it true that by August 31, 2024, Oregon will also officially conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state? The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government, explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection, and the results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

not_P.title: Given California conducts a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024, will Oregon not hold a referendum on abortion rights by August 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, California conducts a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state. The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the state of California, with the primary focus on abortion rights protection, and the results publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

Then, is it true that by August 31, 2024, Oregon will also not officially conduct a public referendum specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in the state? The referendum must be officially announced and conducted by the Oregon state government, explicitly address the issue of abortion rights protection, and the results must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

para_P.title: If California holds a vote on abortion rights by August 2024, will Oregon also conduct a vote on abortion rights by that same date?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following scenario: By August 31, 2024, California will have carried out a public vote aimed at establishing protections for abortion rights within the state. This vote must be formally announced and executed by the state of California, centering on the protection of abortion rights, with the outcomes reported by official state channels or reputable news outlets.

In that case, can we confirm that by August 31, 2024, Oregon will similarly hold an official public vote focused on securing protections for abortion rights within the state? This vote must be formally announced and conducted by the Oregon state government, directly addressing the matter of abortion rights protection, with the results made public through official state channels or well-known news organizations.

question.title: Will both California and Oregon conduct referendums on abortion rights by August 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, both California and Oregon conduct public referendums specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in their respective states. For a YES resolution:

1. Each state must officially announce and conduct its own referendum.
2. The primary focus of each referendum must be on abortion rights protection.
3. The results of each referendum must be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if either state does not conduct such a referendum meeting these criteria by August 31, 2024. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does not qualify for a YES resolution.

not_P.title: Will neither California nor Oregon conduct referendums on abortion rights by August 2024?
not_P.body:
This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, neither California nor Oregon conduct public referendums specifically focused on enshrining protection for abortion rights in their respective states. For a YES resolution:

1. Each state must not officially announce and conduct its own referendum.
2. The primary focus of each referendum must not be on abortion rights protection.
3. The results of each referendum must not be publicly reported by official state channels or widely recognized news sources.

The question will resolve as NO if either state does conduct such a referendum meeting these criteria by August 31, 2024. Note that merely proposing or planning a referendum without actually conducting it by the specified date does qualify for a YES resolution.

para_P.title: Are California and Oregon both going to hold referendums regarding abortion rights before August 2024?
para_P.body:
This inquiry will be deemed affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, both California and Oregon hold public referendums aimed specifically at establishing protections for abortion rights within their states. For an affirmative outcome:

1. Each state must formally declare and carry out its own referendum.
2. The central theme of each referendum must be the safeguarding of abortion rights.
3. The outcomes of each referendum must be disclosed through official state channels or widely acknowledged news outlets.

The inquiry will be considered negative if either state fails to conduct such a referendum that meets these stipulations by August 31, 2024. It is important to note that simply suggesting or planning a referendum without actually executing it by the designated date does not fulfill the criteria for an affirmative outcome.

question.title: Will the Philippine government enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. If no such enforcement meeting these criteria is confirmed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the Philippine government not enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are no confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' in this context means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. If such enforcement meeting these criteria is confirmed by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Philippine authorities implement a closure of online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if, by July 31, 2024, there are verified reports indicating that the Philippine authorities have effectively executed a closure of online trading platforms run by Chinese entities in the Philippines. The execution must be reported by at least two credible international news agencies (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve formal government actions leading to the termination of operations for a considerable number of these trading platforms. 'Considerable' in this context means at least 50% of the recognized online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The closure must stem from government policy or directive, rather than voluntary shutdowns or economic circumstances. If no such enforcement meeting these criteria is confirmed by the resolution date, the inquiry resolves as NO.

question.title: Given the Philippine government enforces a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms by July 2024, will the IMF announce new funding commitments over $400 million by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, there are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms. This enforcement must involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for at least 50% of these platforms and be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations. The shutdown must result from government policy or directive.

Then, is it true that by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund will officially announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million? These announcements must be made through official IMF channels and reported by at least two reputable news sources. The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs.

not_P.title: Given the Philippine government does not enforce a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms by July 2024, will the IMF not announce new funding commitments over $400 million by July 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, there are no confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms. This enforcement must involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for at least 50% of these platforms and be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations. The shutdown must result from government policy or directive.

Then, is it true that by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund will not officially announce new funding commitments totaling over $400 million? These announcements must be made through official IMF channels and reported by at least two reputable news sources. The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs.

para_P.title: If the Philippine government implements a ban on online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities by July 2024, will the International Monetary Fund reveal new financial commitments exceeding $400 million by that same date?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following is accurate: By July 31, 2024, there are verified accounts indicating that the Philippine government has effectively carried out a ban on online trading platforms managed by Chinese interests. This ban must entail official government measures leading to the closure of at least 50% of these platforms and be covered by a minimum of two credible international news outlets. The ban must stem from a government policy or directive.

Then, is it accurate to say that by July 31, 2024, the International Monetary Fund will formally disclose new financial commitments amounting to over $400 million? These disclosures must be made through official IMF communication channels and reported by at least two trustworthy news organizations. The financial commitments must represent new initiatives or substantial expansions of current programs.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Philippine government enforces a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms, and (b) the IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If both conditions are not met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the Philippine government enforces a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms, nor (b) the IMF announces new funding commitments totaling over $400 million?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if neither of the following occur by July 31, 2024: (a) There are confirmed reports that the Philippine government has successfully enforced a shutdown of Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines. The enforcement must be reported by at least two reputable international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and involve official government actions leading to the cessation of operations for a significant number of these trading platforms. 'Significant' means at least 50% of known Chinese-run online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of enforcement. The shutdown must be a result of government policy or directive, not due to voluntary closures or economic factors. (b) The International Monetary Fund officially announces one or more new funding commitments that collectively total more than $400 million. The announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (such as their website or press releases) and be reported by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The funding commitments must be new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, not continuations of previously announced commitments. If both conditions are met by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it possible that by July 2024, both of the following will take place: (a) the government of the Philippines imposes a ban on online trading platforms operated by Chinese entities, and (b) the IMF reveals new financial commitments exceeding $400 million?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed TRUE if both of the following conditions are satisfied by July 31, 2024: (a) There are verified reports indicating that the Philippine government has effectively imposed a ban on online trading platforms managed by Chinese operators in the Philippines. The enforcement must be confirmed by no fewer than two credible international news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, or CNN) and must involve official government actions that lead to the suspension of operations for a substantial number of these trading platforms. 'Substantial' refers to at least 50% of the known Chinese-operated online trading platforms in the Philippines at the time of the ban. The closure must stem from government policy or directive, rather than voluntary shutdowns or economic reasons. (b) The International Monetary Fund formally announces one or more new financial commitments that in total exceed $400 million. Such announcement(s) must be made through official IMF channels (like their website or press releases) and reported by at least two reputable news outlets (e.g., Reuters, Associated Press, New York Times, Wall Street Journal). The financial commitments must represent new initiatives or significant expansions of existing programs, rather than extensions of previously disclosed commitments. If both conditions are not fulfilled by the resolution date, the inquiry will be considered FALSE.

question.title: Will PepsiCo report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If no such increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports continued decline or stagnation in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will PepsiCo not report increased North American demand for its Tostitos brand by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, PepsiCo does not report an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. The lack of increase must be confirmed through official company earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and reported by at least two reputable news sources (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The demand increase should not be explicitly stated or clearly implied in the company's financial results or official communications. If such an increase is reported by the specified date, or if PepsiCo reports an increase in demand for Tostitos in North America, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: By July 2024, will there be a rise in North American demand for Tostitos as reported by PepsiCo?
para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude with a YES if, on or before July 31, 2024, PepsiCo indicates an upturn in North American demand for its Tostitos brand in comparison to the demand noted in the second quarter of 2023. This increase must be validated through official earnings reports or statements from PepsiCo and acknowledged by at least two credible news outlets (such as Reuters, Bloomberg, CNBC, or The Wall Street Journal). The rise in demand should be explicitly mentioned or clearly suggested in the company's financial disclosures or official announcements. If there is no such increase reported by the designated date, or if PepsiCo indicates a continued decrease or stagnation in Tostitos demand in North America, the inquiry will conclude with a NO.

question.title: Given increased North American demand for Tostitos, will U.S. jobless claims exceed 200,000 for four weeks?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, PepsiCo reports an increase in North American demand for its Tostitos brand compared to the demand reported in the second quarter of 2023. question.title: Will the Reserve Bank of Australia announce an interest rate cut by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Reserve Bank of Australia officially announces a decrease in its cash rate target by July 31, 2024. The interest rate cut must be a formal decision made by the Reserve Bank Board and communicated in their official statement or press conference following a meeting. Any speculation about future rate cuts or unofficial statements by individual RBA members will not count for resolution. If no such official announcement of an interest rate cut is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO.

The implementation must not be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must not be a new initiative aimed at forgiving student loan debt for a significant number of borrowers. If such implementation occurs by the resolution date, or if the plan is not blocked by further legal challenges, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is the U.S. Education Department going to establish a program to cancel student loan debt by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if, by July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has effectively established a program to cancel student loan debt. Confirmation of the implementation must come from official statements by the U.S. Education Department or coverage by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The initiative must be a new effort aimed at cancelling student loan debt for a considerable number of borrowers. If such implementation does not occur by the resolution date, or if the initiative faces further legal obstacles, the inquiry will be answered with NO.

question.title: Given the U.S. Education Department implements a plan to forgive student loan debt by July 2024, will California hold a referendum on abortion rights by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has successfully implemented a plan to forgive student loan debt, confirmed by official announcements or reported by at least two major news outlets. The plan must be a new initiative aimed at forgiving student loan debt for a significant number of borrowers.

Given this, will California officially conduct a statewide referendum specifically on the topic of enshrining abortion rights in the state constitution by July 31, 2024? The referendum must be formally announced by the California state government and verified by at least two major news organizations. It must be open to all eligible voters in California and focus primarily on abortion rights. If no such referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if it is canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Given the U.S. Education Department implements a plan to forgive student loan debt by July 2024, will California not hold a referendum on abortion rights by July 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the U.S. Education Department has successfully implemented a plan to forgive student loan debt, confirmed by official announcements or reported by at least two major news outlets. If such a referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if it is not canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, the question resolves as YES.

para_P.title: If the U.S. Education Department executes a strategy to eliminate student loan debt by July 2024, will California conduct a vote on abortion rights by July 2024?

In light of this, will California officially carry out a statewide vote specifically regarding the inclusion of abortion rights in the state constitution by July 31, 2024? The vote must be formally declared by the California state government and validated by at least two major news outlets. It should be accessible to all eligible voters in California and primarily concentrate on abortion rights. If such a vote does not take place or is not finalized by the resolution date, or if it is canceled or delayed beyond July 31, 2024, the question will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will both of the following occur by July 2024: (a) the U.S. Education Department implements a plan to forgive student loan debt, and (b) California holds a referendum on abortion rights?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur by July 31, 2024: (a) The U.S. Education Department successfully implements a plan to forgive student loan debt. The implementation must be confirmed by official announcements from the U.S. Education Department or reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, or Wall Street Journal). The plan must be a new initiative aimed at forgiving student loan debt for a significant number of borrowers. The referendum must be formally announced by the California state government and verified by at least two major news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, NPR, or major California-based news outlets). The referendum must be open to all eligible voters in California and focus primarily on abortion rights. If no such referendum occurs or is completed by the resolution date, or if the referendum is canceled or postponed beyond July 31, 2024, this part will resolve as NO. The question will resolve as YES only if both parts are satisfied.

para_P.body: This inquiry will conclude as YES if both of the following take place by July 31, 2024: (a) The U.S. Education Department effectively carries out a strategy to eliminate student loan debt. question.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

not_P.title: Will the average rate on a 15-year mortgage not exceed 5.5% by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, does not exceed 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate exceeds 5.5% at any point during August 2024, the question resolves as NO. For clarity, the rate must not surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

para_P.title: Will the typical interest rate for a 15-year mortgage surpass 5.5% before the end of August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with a YES if, at any time in August 2024, the typical interest rate for a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as documented by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, goes beyond 5.5%. The rate must be verified by official publications from Freddie Mac or trusted financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any moment during August 2024, the answer will be NO. To be clear, the rate must go beyond 5.5%, not just reach it.

question.title: Conditional on the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceeding 5.5% by August 2024, will Nevada maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: At any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

Then, is it also true that as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher? The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

not_P.title: Conditional on the average rate on a 15-year mortgage not exceeding 5.5% by August 2024, will Nevada not maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: At any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, does not exceed 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. The rate must not surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

Then, is it also true that as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada does not remain at $11 per hour or higher? The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, the question resolves as YES. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

para_P.title: Assuming that the average interest rate for a 15-year mortgage is above 5.5% by August 2024, will the minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada stay at $11 per hour or more until July 2024?
para_P.body:
Let’s consider this scenario: At any time during August 2024, the average interest rate on a 15-year fixed mortgage, as indicated by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, is greater than 5.5%. This rate must be validated by official publications from Freddie Mac or trustworthy financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. It is essential that the rate exceeds 5.5%, rather than just matching it.

In this case, is it also accurate that by July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada is maintained at $11 per hour or above? This wage must be verified through official announcements from the state of Nevada or reports from at least two credible news organizations (like the Associated Press, Reuters, or prominent national newspapers). If the wage drops below $11 per hour at any time before the resolution date, the answer will be NO. For the purposes of this inquiry, 'fast food employees' are defined as workers in fast food establishments according to Nevada state law.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceeds 5.5% by August 2024, and (b) Nevada maintains its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
question.body:
(a) This part of the question resolves as YES if, at any point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must be confirmed by official reports from Freddie Mac or reputable financial news sources such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any point during August 2024, this part resolves as NO. The rate must surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

(b) This part of the question resolves as YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or higher. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage is reduced below $11 per hour at any point by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'fast food workers' refers to employees in fast food restaurants as defined by Nevada state law.

The overall question resolves as YES if both (a) and (b) resolve as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will at least one of the following not occur: (a) the average rate on a 15-year mortgage exceeds 5.5% by August 2024, or (b) Nevada does not maintain its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food workers through July 2024?
not_P.body:
(a) This part of the question resolves as YES if, at no point during August 2024, the average rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as reported by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, exceeds 5.5%. The rate must not surpass 5.5%, not merely equal it.

(b) This part of the question resolves as YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food workers in Nevada is reduced below $11 per hour. The wage must be confirmed through official Nevada state announcements or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage remains at $11 per hour or higher at any point by the resolution date, this part resolves as NO.

The overall question resolves as YES if at least one of (a) or (b) resolves as YES. Otherwise, it resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) the average interest rate on a 15-year mortgage will go above 5.5% by August 2024, and (b) Nevada will keep its $11 per hour minimum wage for fast food employees until July 2024?
para_P.body:
(a) This segment of the inquiry is answered with YES if, at any time during August 2024, the average interest rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage, as documented by Freddie Mac in its Primary Mortgage Market Survey, surpasses 5.5%. The rate needs to be validated by official reports from Freddie Mac or credible financial news outlets such as Bloomberg, Reuters, or The Wall Street Journal. If the rate does not exceed 5.5% at any time during August 2024, this segment is answered with NO. The rate must go above 5.5%, not just equal it.

(b) This segment of the inquiry is answered with YES if, as of July 31, 2024, the minimum wage for fast food employees in Nevada remains at $11 per hour or more. The wage must be verified through official announcements from the state of Nevada or reports from at least two reputable news organizations (such as Associated Press, Reuters, or major national newspapers). If the wage drops below $11 per hour at any time before the resolution date, this segment is answered with NO. For the purposes of this inquiry, 'fast food employees' refers to workers in fast food establishments as defined by Nevada state law.

The overall inquiry is answered with YES if both (a) and (b) are answered with YES. Otherwise, it is answered with NO.

question.title: Will a court rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no such ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court without a formal ruling, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator liable; it only requires a ruling to be made on the matter of liability.

not_P.title: Will a court not rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, a court of law does not issue a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If such a ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court with a formal ruling, the question resolves as NO. Note that this question does not require the court to find the operator not liable; it only requires that no ruling is made on the matter of liability.

para_P.title: Will there be a judicial decision regarding the responsibility of a prominent hotel chain operator by the end of August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be considered affirmative if, by August 31, 2024, a judicial authority issues a decision on whether a prominent hotel chain operator bears responsibility for negligence or gross negligence relating to an event that caused substantial harm or loss. The decision must be recorded in official legal documents and covered by at least two major news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If such a decision is not made by the specified date, or if the matter is resolved outside of court without an official ruling, the inquiry will be deemed negative. It is important to note that this question does not necessitate the court to determine the operator's liability; it merely requires a decision to be rendered regarding the issue of liability.

question.title: Conditional on a court ruling on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024, will the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence related to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). 

Then, will the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) report a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024? The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC).

not_P.title: Conditional on a court ruling on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024, will the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase not exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence related to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). 

Then, will the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) report a month-over-month increase not greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024? The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC).

para_P.title: Dependent on a judicial decision regarding the accountability of a significant hotel chain operator by August 2024, will the Federal Reserve's favored inflation indicator reflect a monthly rise surpassing 0.5% by July 2024?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By August 31, 2024, a judicial body delivers a verdict on the accountability of a significant hotel chain operator concerning negligence or gross negligence linked to an event causing considerable damage or loss. This verdict must be recorded in official court documentation and covered by at least two prominent news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). 

Then, will the Federal Reserve's favored inflation indicator (usually the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) indicate a month-over-month rise exceeding 0.5% in any month from October 2023 to July 31, 2024? This increase must be officially disclosed by the Federal Reserve or an appropriate U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two credible financial news outlets (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC).

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) a court rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024 and (b) the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if both of the following conditions are met: (a) By August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If no such ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court without a formal ruling, this condition resolves as NO. (b) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is reported during this period, this condition resolves as NO. Both conditions must be met for this question to resolve as YES.

not_P.title: Will neither of the following occur: (a) a court rule on the liability of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024 nor (b) the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure show a monthly increase exceeding 0.5% by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if neither of the following conditions are met: (a) By August 31, 2024, a court of law issues a ruling on whether a major hotel chain operator is liable for negligence or gross negligence in relation to an incident resulting in significant harm or loss. The ruling must be documented in official court records and reported by at least two major news outlets (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If such a ruling occurs by the resolution date, or if the case is settled out of court with a formal ruling, this condition resolves as YES. (b) The Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure (typically the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) reports a month-over-month increase greater than 0.5% in any single month between October 2023 and July 31, 2024. The increase must be officially published by the Federal Reserve or a relevant U.S. government agency (such as the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two reputable financial news sources (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If such an increase is reported during this period, this condition resolves as YES. Neither condition must be met for this question to resolve as YES.

para_P.title: Will a court decide on the responsibility of a major hotel chain operator by August 2024 while also seeing the Federal Reserve's key inflation gauge rise by more than 0.5% before July 2024?
para_P.body: This question will be answered with YES if both of the following criteria are satisfied: (a) A court of law issues a decision regarding the liability of a major hotel chain operator for negligence or gross negligence related to an incident that caused significant damage or loss by August 31, 2024. This decision must be recorded in official court documents and covered by at least two major news organizations (such as Reuters, Associated Press, BBC, CNN, or The New York Times). If such a decision is not made by the resolution date, or if the case is resolved outside of court without a formal ruling, this condition will be marked as NO. (b) The Federal Reserve's primary inflation measure (usually the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index or PCE) must show a month-over-month increase exceeding 0.5% in any month from October 2023 until July 31, 2024. This increase must be officially released by the Federal Reserve or a pertinent U.S. government agency (like the Bureau of Economic Analysis) and reported by at least two credible financial news outlets (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, Wall Street Journal, CNBC). If no such increase is reported during this timeframe, this condition will be marked as NO. Both criteria must be fulfilled for this question to be answered with YES.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris announce her running mate at a rally in San Diego by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally. If Harris does not make such an announcement at a San Diego rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, the question will resolve as NO.

not_P.title: Will Kamala Harris not announce her running mate at a rally in San Diego by August 2024?
not_P.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris does not publicly announce her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. The announcement must not be made by Harris herself during the rally and must not clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must not be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally. If Harris does make such an announcement at a San Diego rally by the end of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through other means or at a different location, the question will resolve as NO.

para_P.title: Will Kamala Harris reveal her selection for a running mate at a San Diego rally before August 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be deemed YES if, by August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris officially discloses her choice for a running mate for the upcoming election at a rally taking place in San Diego, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must distinctly name the person selected as her running mate. The event and announcement must be validated by at least two credible national news outlets (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours following the rally. If Harris fails to make such a disclosure at a San Diego rally by the conclusion of August 2024, or if the announcement is made through alternative channels or at a different venue, the question will be resolved as NO.

question.title: Given Kamala Harris announces her running mate at a rally in San Diego by August 2024, will the E. coli outbreak tied to beef result in more than 10 confirmed deaths by August 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally.

Then, is it true that by August 31, 2024, there are official reports confirming more than 10 deaths attributed to the E. coli outbreak linked to beef from a specific supplier? Official confirmation must come from credible sources such as the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) or equivalent health authorities, and be reported by at least two reputable news outlets. The death toll must be specifically linked to this outbreak and not include deaths from unrelated E. coli cases. If the death toll remains at 10 or fewer by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, only deaths directly attributed to this specific outbreak will be counted.

not_P.title: Given Kamala Harris announces her running mate at a rally in San Diego by August 2024, will the E. coli outbreak tied to beef result in 10 or fewer confirmed deaths by August 2024?
not_P.body:
Suppose the following is true: By August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris publicly announces her running mate for the upcoming election at a rally held in San Diego, California. The announcement must be made by Harris herself during the rally and must clearly identify the individual chosen as her running mate. The event and announcement must be confirmed by at least two reputable national news sources (such as Associated Press, Reuters, New York Times, Washington Post, CNN, or Fox News) within 24 hours of the rally.

Then, is it true that by August 31, 2024, there are no official reports confirming more than 10 deaths attributed to the E. coli outbreak linked to beef from a specific supplier? Official confirmation must come from credible sources such as the CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) or equivalent health authorities, and be reported by at least two reputable news outlets. The death toll must be specifically linked to this outbreak and not include deaths from unrelated E. coli cases. If the death toll remains at 10 or fewer by the resolution date, the question resolves as YES. For the purpose of this question, only deaths directly attributed to this specific outbreak will be counted.

para_P.title: If Kamala Harris declares her choice for a running mate at a San Diego rally by August 2024, will the E. coli outbreak associated with beef lead to over 10 confirmed fatalities by that date?
para_P.body:
Assuming the following holds true: By August 31, 2024, Vice President Kamala Harris makes a public declaration of her running mate for the upcoming election during a rally in San Diego, California. This announcement must be delivered by Harris herself at the rally and must explicitly name the individual selected as her running mate. question.title: Will Alibaba Group resolve a major workers' strike by July 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as YES if Alibaba Group reaches an agreement with unionized workers, resulting in the end of a significant strike by July 31, 2024. For the resolution to be considered valid:

1. The strike must involve a substantial number of Alibaba Group workers (at least 1,000 participants).
2. The strike must last for at least one week.
3. The resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union.
4. The resolution must be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

If no such resolution meeting all these criteria is achieved by the specified date, or if no significant strike occurs, the question resolves as NO.

3. The resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Alibaba Group and the involved union.
4. The resolution must not be reported by at least two reputable international news sources (e.g., Reuters, AP, Bloomberg, BBC).

question.title: Will the Central Bank of Mexico announce an interest rate cut by August 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if the Central Bank of Mexico officially announces an interest rate cut to take effect by August 31, 2024. The announcement must be confirmed by official Bank of Mexico communications, such as press releases, Governing Board statements, or public speeches by Bank officials. If no such announcement is made by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. Note that the actual implementation date of the rate cut can be after August 31, 2024, as long as the announcement itself occurs by that date. The interest rate in question refers to the target for the overnight interbank interest rate, which is the Central Bank of Mexico's primary tool for monetary policy.

question.title: Will the lawsuit against Massachusetts' initiative on crisis pregnancy centers be ongoing in August 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as YES if, by August 31, 2024, the lawsuit filed by a conservative law firm against Massachusetts' initiative targeting crisis pregnancy centers is still ongoing in court. The status of the lawsuit must be confirmed through official court documents or reported by at least two reputable news sources. If the lawsuit has been dismissed, settled, or reached a final judgment by the resolution date, the question resolves as NO. For the purpose of this question, 'ongoing' means the case is still in active litigation, including any appeals process.

not_P.title: Will either of the following not occur: (a) The lawsuit against Massachusetts' initiative on crisis pregnancy centers be ongoing in August 2024, or (b) Alabama not enact new abortion regulations stricter than those for other healthcare providers by July 2024?
not_P.body: This question resolves as YES if at least one of the following conditions is met: (1) By August 31, 2024, the lawsuit filed by a conservative law firm against Massachusetts' initiative targeting crisis pregnancy centers is not ongoing in court. The status of the lawsuit must be confirmed through official court documents or reported by at least two reputable news sources. If the lawsuit has been dismissed, settled, or reached a final judgment by the resolution date, the question resolves as YES. For the purpose of this question, 'not ongoing' means the case is no longer in active litigation, including any appeals process. (2) By July 31, 2024, Alabama does not enact new laws or regulations that impose stricter requirements on abortion providers compared to other healthcare providers. The enactment must be confirmed by official state legislative documentation or reported by at least two reputable news sources. If no such laws or regulations are enacted by the resolution date, or if any enacted laws or regulations apply equally to all healthcare providers, the question will resolve as YES.

para_P.title: Is it true that both of the following will happen: (a) The legal action against Massachusetts' initiative on crisis pregnancy centers will still be in progress in August 2024, and (b) Alabama will implement new abortion regulations that are more stringent than those for other healthcare providers by July 2024?
para_P.body: This inquiry will be answered with YES if both of the following criteria are satisfied: (1) By August 31, 2024, the lawsuit initiated by a conservative law firm against Massachusetts' initiative aimed at crisis pregnancy centers is still in active litigation. If the lawsuit has been dismissed, settled, or concluded with a final ruling by the resolution date, the answer will be NO. For this question, 'active litigation' indicates that the case is still being pursued in court, including any appeals. (2) By July 31, 2024, Alabama passes new laws or regulations that impose stricter standards on abortion providers than those applied to other healthcare providers. The passage must be confirmed by official state legislative documents or reported by at least two reputable news outlets. Stricter standards may encompass, but are not restricted to, additional licensing, reporting, or facility requirements specific to abortion providers. If no such laws or regulations are enacted by the resolution date, or if any laws or regulations enacted are applicable equally to all healthcare providers, the answer will resolve as NO.

question.title: Will the Washington Lottery offer online products by July 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as YES if, by July 31, 2024, the Washington Lottery has officially launched any of its products for online purchase or play. Confirmation must come from an official announcement by the Washington Lottery or reports from at least two reputable news sources (such as local Washington newspapers, national news outlets, or industry-specific publications). The online products must be accessible to the general public within Washington and allow for real-money transactions. Beta testing phases or limited rollouts to select groups do not qualify for a YES resolution. If the Washington Lottery does not offer online products meeting these criteria by July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

not_P.title: Will the Washington Lottery not offer online products by July 2024?

If the Washington Lottery offers online products meeting these criteria by July 31, 2024, the question resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Will the Washington State Lottery provide online gaming options by July 2024?

question.title: If the Washington Lottery offers online products by July 2024, will Google resolve a major workers' strike by then?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: By July 31, 2024, the Washington Lottery has officially launched any of its products for online purchase or play. Confirmation must come from an official announcement by the Washington Lottery or reports from at least two reputable news sources. The online products must be accessible to the general public within Washington and allow for real-money transactions. Beta testing phases or limited rollouts to select groups do not qualify.

Then, will Google resolve a major workers' strike by July 31, 2024? This resolves YES if Google reaches an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by that date. The strike must involve at least 1,000 participants, last at least one week, and the resolution must be confirmed by official statements from both Google and the union, and reported by at least two reputable international news sources. If no such resolution occurs, or if no significant strike occurs, it resolves as NO.

not_P.title: If the Washington Lottery does not offer online products by July 2024, will Google not resolve a major workers' strike by then?
not_P.body:

Confirmation must come from an official announcement by the Washington Lottery or reports from at least two reputable news sources. The online products must not be accessible to the general public within Washington or allow for real-money transactions. Beta testing phases or limited rollouts to select groups do not qualify.

Then, will Google not resolve a major workers' strike by July 31, 2024? This resolves YES if Google does not reach an agreement with unionized workers, ending a significant strike by that date. The strike must involve at least 1,000 participants, last at least one week, and the resolution must not be confirmed by official statements from both Google and the union, and reported by at least two reputable international news sources. If such a resolution occurs, or if a significant strike does not occur, it resolves as NO.

para_P.title: Should the Washington Lottery introduce online offerings by July 2024, will Google successfully settle a significant workers' strike by that time?
